answers.author: Rob Hines
answers.text:
Hey Ray,  
Excellent question. I think there is likely a long list of answers to this question on many levels but let me focus on a few key points that I think local governments can employ on a practical level to help increase civility.  
-Ensuring that the public at large feels comfortable participating in a discussion is really important. In a polarized heated debate those moderate voices can shy away from conflict, which is what you do not want to happen. Moderate voices really do moderate the debate by encouraging people of varying opinion to participate in a debate. 
Further, people are really smart and many will seek out the opinions of others in a forum before forming their own opinion. So, on a basic level, before a local government institutes a discussion they should set guidelines for civility, or the ground rules for discussion, at the outset.  
Open Town Hall, an online civic engagement platform used by many local governments works to create 'guidelines for civility' to inform participants of the ground rules before they contribute to an open and transparent discussion.  
-Another key point connected to the last is to address profanity, personal attacks, and other unsavory comments when they occur. Open Town Hall has a mechanism for reviewing each comment on a forum and reconciles 'uncivil' behaviour in a non-confrontational way without limiting free speech. We've managed to get the 'uncivil' comment rate down to .02% and half of those comments are simply 'off-topic'. Those guidelines for civility head most off at the pass!  
-Much of the vitriol and bullying found on public forums come from anonymous individuals. Preventing anonymous comments in a forum sponsored by a local government really does a lot to improve the integrity of the comments and create a true public discussion. 
-Last but not least, people make the best decisions and form the best opinions when they have all of the information. This can level the playing field and create an atmosphere of empowerment and trust. Civil dialogue and open data are really important here. 
-Of course, there are many other ways to increase civility between opposing factions and it would be great to see some more listed by other members with other backgrounds. For more on Open Town Hall, please visit opentownhall.com.  
Cheers,  
Rob

Open dialogue and deliberation is an important factor in keeping the lines of communication open. the National Issues Forum has an excellent model of civic deliberation. http://www.nifi.org/

answers.author: Sarah Read
answers.text:
Ray - I agree with many of Rob's points, and when you are dealing with strongly opposed views careful planning and good facilitators are important for encouraging civility.  You might be interested in this series of blog posts on planning:
http://buildingdialogue.wordpress.com/2011/03/08/setting-yourself-up-for-evaluation/
or this on the hard cases: http://buildingdialogue.wordpress.com/2011/01/11/dealing-with-conflcit-in-the-community/
We just started a series on cognitive errors and how to address them and have other resources as well.

answers.author: Tim Bonnemann
answers.text:
Over the years, the National Coalition for Dialogue and Deliberation (NCDD) has curated lots of resources on this topic, for example: 
http://ncdd.org/rc/?s=civility 
In 2010, they developed a quick-guide for local officials that goes over some of the basics: 
http://ncdd.org/rc/item/3172 
http://ncdd.org/rc/wp-content/uploads/2010/08/NCDDTownHallFlyer.pdf 
Let me know if you find anything interesting there.
